body:
I should note, that I did create a RSA public/private key pair, and added the public key to authorized_keys  file in my servers's ~/.ssh directory.

Using git-bash, I was able to confirm that the SSH key's was working, however I still get the same error:

```
ogi@OGI-DESKTOP ~/Downloads
$ ipython qtconsole --existing ./kernel-2050.json --ssh hwvmsrv
c:\Users\ogi\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\paramiko\client.py:580: UserWarning: U
nknown ssh-rsa host key for hwvmsrv: b'96b38225fac1d25f1f78ebb913d32f3d'
  (key.get_name(), hostname, hexlify(key.get_fingerprint())))
[IPythonQtConsoleApp] ERROR | Could not setup tunnels
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "c:\Users\ogi\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\IPython\consoleapp.py", line 2
39, in init_ssh
    newports = tunnel_to_kernel(info, self.sshserver, self.sshkey)
  File "c:\Users\ogi\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\IPython\kernel\connect.py", li
ne 357, in tunnel_to_kernel
    if tunnel.try_passwordless_ssh(sshserver, sshkey):
  File "c:\Users\ogi\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\zmq\ssh\tunnel.py", line 78, i
n try_passwordless_ssh
    return f(server, keyfile)
  File "c:\Users\ogi\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\zmq\ssh\tunnel.py", line 122,
in _try_passwordless_paramiko
    look_for_keys=True)
  File "c:\Users\ogi\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\paramiko\client.py", line 307,
 in connect
    look_for_keys, gss_auth, gss_kex, gss_deleg_creds, gss_host)
  File "c:\Users\ogi\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\paramiko\client.py", line 444,
 in _auth
    key = pkey_class.from_private_key_file(key_filename, password)
  File "c:\Users\ogi\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\paramiko\pkey.py", line 183, i
n from_private_key_file
    key = cls(filename=filename, password=password)
  File "c:\Users\ogi\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\paramiko\rsakey.py", line 55,
in __init__
    self._from_private_key_file(filename, password)
  File "c:\Users\ogi\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\paramiko\rsakey.py", line 165,
 in _from_private_key_file
    data = self._read_private_key_file('RSA', filename, password)
  File "c:\Users\ogi\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\paramiko\pkey.py", line 254, i
n _read_private_key_file
    with open(filename, 'r') as f:
FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: ''

ogi@OGI-DESKTOP ~/Downloads
$ ssh ogi@hwvmsrv
Welcome to Ubuntu 14.04.2 LTS (GNU/Linux 3.16.0-37-generic x86_64)

 * Documentation:  https://help.ubuntu.com/

  System information as of Sat May 16 20:22:02 PDT 2015

  System load:  0.0                Processes:           107
  Usage of /:   35.2% of 17.58GB   Users logged in:     1
  Memory usage: 6%                 IP address for eth0: 10.0.2.15
  Swap usage:   0%                 IP address for eth1: 192.168.56.101

  Graph this data and manage this system at:
    https://landscape.canonical.com/

Last login: Sat May 16 20:22:03 2015 from 192.168.56.1
ogi@hwvmsrv:~$
```

Is your paramiko up to date? Where is the private key saved on your local machine. You can see where paramiko looks [here](https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/blob/v1.15.2/paramiko/client.py#L470).

I think there's a bug in paramiko, at least in that it should fail earlier with a more meaningful error, rather than trying to open `''` as a file.

Paramiko is version 1.15.2, pycrypto is 2.6.1.

On my local machine, my keys are in ~/.ssh  ; or more specifically: `"C:\Users\ogi\.ssh\id_rsa"`

How would it be best to try and isolate the bug to paramiko itself; or should I open an issue in their repo?

The relevant lines of code running in pyzmq are here:

https://github.com/zeromq/pyzmq/blob/v14.6.0/zmq/ssh/tunnel.py#L117

If you can replicate the error by running just those lines, that isolates it to Paramiko.

Thanks for following up.

I guess this looks like a problem with paramiko:

```
ogi@OGI-DESKTOP ~/Downloads
$ ssh ogi@hwvmsrv
Welcome to Ubuntu 14.04.2 LTS (GNU/Linux 3.16.0-37-generic x86_64)

0 updates are security updates.

logout
Connection to hwvmsrv closed.

ogi@OGI-DESKTOP ~/Downloads
$ ipython

.1600 64 bit (AMD64)]

IPython 3.1.0 -- An enhanced Interactive Python.

help      -> Python's own help system.
object?   -> Details about 'object', use 'object??' for extra details.

In [1]: import paramiko

In [2]: client = paramiko.SSHClient()

In [3]: client.load_system_host_keys()

In [4]: server = 'hwvmsrv'

In [5]: username = 'ogi'

In [6]: port = 22

In [7]: keyfile = "C:\\Users\\ogi\\.ssh\\id_rsa"

In [8]: client.connect(server, port, username=username, key_filename=keyfile, lo
ok_for_keys=True)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
SSHException                              Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-8-68c07a1ff1cf> in <module>()
----> 1 client.connect(server, port, username=username, key_filename=keyfile, lo
ok_for_keys=True)

c:\Users\ogi\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\paramiko\client.py in connect(self, ho
stname, port, username, password, pkey, key_filename, timeout, allow_agent, look
_for_keys, compress, sock, gss_auth, gss_kex, gss_deleg_creds, gss_host, banner_
timeout)
    286                 # will raise exception if the key is rejected; let that
fall out
    287                 self._policy.missing_host_key(self, server_hostkey_name,

--> 288                                               server_key)
    289                 # if the callback returns, assume the key is ok
    290                 our_server_key = server_key

c:\Users\ogi\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\paramiko\client.py in missing_host_key
(self, client, hostname, key)
    568         client._log(DEBUG, 'Rejecting %s host key for %s: %s' %
    569                     (key.get_name(), hostname, hexlify(key.get_fingerpri
nt())))
--> 570         raise SSHException('Server %r not found in known_hosts' % hostna
me)
    571
    572

SSHException: Server 'hwvmsrv' not found in known_hosts
```

Line 1 of my known_hosts file (in the same directory as my RSA key) is 

```
hwvmsrv,192.168.1.130 ecdsa-sha2-nistp256 AAAAE2VjZHNh...
```

triple dot indicating the key extends a ways.

Ah, looking at that more closely, I think the original problem may not be in paramiko - it looks like we're passing in an empty string for keyfile. Possibly we should be passing `None` if a key is not specified instead. @minrk ?

Don't know about the new error.

I'll open up an issue regarding the known_hosts extension and see what they have to say.

Thanks for investigating.

Will investigate this weekend
On Jun 12, 2015 11:19 AM, "Matthias Bussonnier" notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Has this been solved ?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/8439#issuecomment-111579744.

> Will investigate this weekend

No hurry .

I just confirmed the issue still exists:

```
[server] 
$ ipython kernel
...

To connect another client to this kernel, use:
   --existing kernel-15047.json
```

I then retrieve the kernel-15047.json file, and edit the ip address to match the ip address of the server

```

$ ipython qtconsole --existing ./kernel-15047.json --ssh hwvmsrv

nknown ssh-rsa host key for hwvmsrv: b'96b38225fac1d25f1f78ebb913d32f3d'

39, in init_ssh
    newports = tunnel_to_kernel(info, self.sshserver, self.sshkey)

ne 357, in tunnel_to_kernel
    if tunnel.try_passwordless_ssh(sshserver, sshkey):

n try_passwordless_ssh
    return f(server, keyfile)
  File "c:\Users\ogi\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\zmq\ssh\tunnel.py", line 122,
in _try_passwordless_paramiko
    look_for_keys=True)
  File "c:\Users\ogi\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\paramiko\client.py", line 307,
 in connect
    look_for_keys, gss_auth, gss_kex, gss_deleg_creds, gss_host)

    key = pkey_class.from_private_key_file(key_filename, password)
  File "c:\Users\ogi\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\paramiko\pkey.py", line 183, i
n from_private_key_file
    key = cls(filename=filename, password=password)

in __init__

n _read_private_key_file
```

To make sure this was just an ipython issue, I managed to establish connectivity with paramiko through git bash.

```
$ ssh ogi@hwvmsrv
Welcome to Ubuntu 14.04.2 LTS (GNU/Linux 3.16.0-37-generic x86_64)
```

Let me know if there is any testing I can do to be of help.

Have the same problem Is there any update on it?
P.S. the problem was solved by "easy_install pexpect"

i also have this problems too. except i do not have private/public key.  the error output just like yours
also, i try to connect the remote ipython kernel (client is wsl, server is ubuntu), it gets stuck
```shell
m@DESKTOP-S5CD00M:/mnt/d/my_work/userlocation$ ipython3 console --existing ./kernel-9337.json --ssh user@xx.xx.xx.xx --debug
```

anyone can help?

I bumped into the same problem. 
The problem is, as @takluyver mentioned, that the default value for the sshkey value created in "jupyter_client/consoleapp.py" is

`sshkey = Unicode('', config=True,
        help="""Path to the ssh key to use for logging in to the ssh server.""")`
[here](https://github.com/jupyter/jupyter_client/blob/50ddc227e0baa9be5e4302621624545e59f4bfa6/jupyter_client/consoleapp.py#L126-L127)
but paramiko only tests for None to see if no keyfile was specified.

First I tried manually setting the sshkey value to None from the command line. 
`jupyter qtconsole --JupyterQtConsoleApp.sshkey=None --existing etc`
which returned 
`[JupyterQtConsoleApp] CRITICAL | The 'sshkey' trait of a JupyterQtConsoleApp instance must be a unicode string, but a value of None <class 'NoneType'> was specified.`

What finally worked, as a quick dirty workaround, was to change the value in the consoleapp.py file (line 122) to default to None. Now things work, but it feels terrible.

What is your opinion on further steps? Should this be closed and an issue be opened at paramiko to include tests for emtpy strings? That's what I would do.

I don't think there's much obvious advantage between making the default `None` and making paramiko test for empty strings. Given what you've found, I'd be fine with making the default None in `jupyter_client`.
